conclusion: We need to determine the average velocity and the average speed of the particle as it moves from point A to point C.
The particle moves along two semicircular arcs, each with a radius of 1 m, from point A to point C.
The displacement is the straight-line distance from the initial position (A) to the final position (C).
The total distance traveled is the sum of the circumferences of the two semicircles: s = πR + πR = 2πR = 2π × 1 = 2π m.

The displacement is the hypotenuse of a right triangle with legs of length 2R = 2 m. Using the Pythagorean theorem, displacement x = √(2R)^2 + (2R)^2 = √(4R^2 + 4R^2) = √(8R^2) = 2√2R = 2√2 × 1 = 2√2 m.
The average velocity is the total displacement divided by the total time: v_avg = displacement / time = (2√2 m) / (5 s) = 2√2 / 5 m/s.
The average speed is the total distance traveled divided by the total time: v_avg = distance / time = (2π m) / (5 s) = 2π / 5 m/s.
The average velocity is 2√2 / 5 m/s and the average speed is 2π / 5 m/s.
